results.brief_description: Covers the purpose and care of feet and the need for properly fitted shoes. Also shows different animals feet and their use. Suitable for lower primary level.

results.title: Health: the inside story
results.brief_description: A common-sense approach to attaining and maintaining good health. Shows the role of muscular endurance, heart and lung endurance and nutrition in a healthy lifestyle. Indicates health hazards such as smoking and stress, and emphasises the need for relaxation. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Health: personal cleanliness. - Second edition.
results.brief_description: In a positive, friendly manner, instructs youngsters who need help forming good hygiene habits and reinforces the attitudes of those whose good habits are already formed. Particular attention is given to cleaning the skin, hair, fingernails, and teeth, and explains why it is necessary.

results.title: Health: communicable diseases. - 2nd edition.
results.creator_credit: AIMS Instructional Media, Michael Wright and David Winter
results.brief_description: Using an animated clay germ to answer the question of how people get sick. The germ tells where germs live and how they are spread from person to person, and then shows how they can be prevented from spreading. Also presents cautionary measures to be taken when sick, along with cautions about taking medicine without grown-up supervision.

results.title: Health, stress and coping
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Carol Trussell and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
In our everyday life, we experience wear and tear, that is, stress. A stressor is anything that requires the body to respond to life by setting off a series of chemical and physical reactions. Individuals respond to, and cope with, stress in different ways, but increasingly scientists are acknowledging the relationship between high levels of stress and the human immune system. This program examines how and why excessive stress affects us.

results.title: Health, mind and behavior
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
In this program, Philip Zimbardo investigates the power the mind has on the functioning of our bodies, in particular, the effect of stress on our health. Increasingly, scientists have had to acknowledge this connection in treating human illness. Zimbardo reveals how a holistic approach to healing, which aims to keep mind and body in harmony, can reduce the impact of stress- related illness such as hypertension and improve the functioning of the human immune system.

results.title: Health service in Britain
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Frank Gardner
results.brief_description: A survey of medical treatment available under Britain’s National Health Scheme. Some of the medical attention which can be obtained on the advice of the general practitioner. Includes specialised services in pre-natal and post-natal care; ophthalmic, dental and orthopaedic treatment; chest clinics; mental health; geriatrics and rehabilitation centres.

results.title: Health of a nation
results.brief_description: A survey of the measures carred out by the British Government to safeguard the people’s health: pre-natal clinics, maternity hospitals, child welfare centres, and school medical services help to ensure that the rising generation is healthy, but the importance of environment is not overlooked. Slums are being replaced by modern housing estates, and special measures are taken to combat industrial diseases which cause ill-health among industrial workers.

results.title: Health of a city
results.creator_credit: Templar Film Studio, Films of Scotland and Riddell Black
results.brief_description: In the early 18th century Glasgow grew into a sprawling, overcrowded city. The squalor and disease which came in its wake was widespread until a medical officer of health was appointed. Modern housing, mass radiography, child care and food examination of today point to the success of those early beginnings in health control.
